analysis: The setting (Elizabeth alone, reading Jane's letters to fuel her anger) provides the emotional powder keg for the encounter.
Darcy's proposal is a masterclass in social awkwardness; he focuses more on the 'degradation' of the match than on his affection.
Elizabeth's rejection is not just about Darcy's personality, but a moral stance against his interference in Jane's happiness and his treatment of Wickham.
Darcy's 'security' of a favorable answer reveals his aristocratic entitlement and lack of understanding of Elizabeth's character.
The 'gentlemanlike manner' comment is the ultimate insult to Darcy, striking at the core of his identity and honor.
The clash of two types of pride: Darcy's social pride versus Elizabeth's pride in her own judgment and moral superiority.
The aftermath (Elizabeth's exhaustion and tears) highlights the massive shift in the novel's trajectory—the dynamic is forever changed.

quotes.quote: In vain have I struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be repressed.
quotes.explanation: Darcy's opening line, acknowledging his internal battle between duty and desire.

quotes.quote: You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love you.
quotes.explanation: Despite his clumsiness, this is one of the most famous declarations in English literature.

quotes.quote: He was not more eloquent on the subject of tenderness than of pride.
quotes.explanation: The narrator's critique of Darcy's inability to separate love from social status.

quotes.quote: I have never desired your good opinion, and you have certainly bestowed it most unwillingly.
quotes.explanation: Elizabeth rejects the idea that his attraction is a compliment she should be grateful for.

quotes.quote: I might as well inquire... why... you chose to tell me that you liked me against your will.
quotes.explanation: Elizabeth calls out the offensive nature of Darcy's 'compliments'.

quotes.quote: You have said quite enough, madam. I perfectly comprehend your feelings.
quotes.explanation: Darcy's exit line, showing his sudden realization of the depth of her dislike.

quotes.quote: I felt that you were the last man in the world whom I could ever be prevailed on to marry.
quotes.explanation: The definitive rejection that marks the lowest point of their relationship.
